chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: This is the manual for the &blyte; screenwriting software. This version of the manual corresponds to version &blyte.version; of the software.

sect1.title: Basic concepts
sect1.para: If you don't know anything about writing a screenplay, get a copy of a book such as Trottier's "The Screenwriter's Bible". This manual will not cover the same ground, but focuses on concepts specific to &blyte;.
&blyte; divides a screenplay into a long list of elements, each with a specific element style. The available element styles are:

listitem.para: Scene header. Example: "INT. MOTEL ROOM - NIGHT".
Describes action. Example: "John grabs the gun from the desk."
A speaking character's name. Example: "HARRY".
Speech. Example: "You could do that, sure. On the other hand, if you want to live beyond the next minute or so, you might want to rethink your approach."
Describes how the actor should say the following dialogue. Example: "(serious)".
Describes a non-standard transition between scenes. Example: "DISSOLVE TO:".
Describes an in-scene shot. Example: "THE NECKLACE".
Note style has a yellow background so it stands out, and is used to insert notes to yourself or to others about that part of the script. Example: "Should Bobby shoot first?".

chapter.title: Basic usage
chapter.para: This chapter discusses basic usage of &blyte;.

sect1.title: Main window
sect1.para: The main window has the following parts in it in top-to-bottom order, after the standard menu bar:

listitem.para: This shows the style of the element the cursor is currently positioned in and allows you to change it.
Each script gets its own tab, with the tab's name being the filename of each script. You can click on each tab to change the active script to that one.
This is where the actual script is shown and edited.
At the bottom is a three-part status bar that shows current page and total page count in the last section, and information about what the Enter/Tab keys would do in the first two sections.

sect2.title: Moving around
sect2.para: The usual movement keys are available: Up/Down/Left/Right to move around, Home/End to move to start/end of line, Page Up/Page Down to move up/down one page (actually one screenful), and CTRL + Home/End to move to start/end of script.
CTRL + Up/Down moves one scene up or down.

sect2.title: Deleting elements
sect2.para: The Delete and Backspace keys delete text one character at a time. They also join elements to one another if pressed at, respectively, at the end or at the start of an element. The joined element will always have the style of the preceding element.

sect2.title: Adding elements and changing their style
sect2.para: The Enter key will always create a new element. If the cursor is at the end of an element, the new element will be an empty one, otherwise the current element is split at the cursor position.
The Tab key will create a new element if the cursor is at the end of an element, otherwise it will switch the current element's style. Shift + Tab will always switch the element's style.

What kind of element Enter/Tab/Shift + Tab will create/switch to is dependent on the current style of the element, and is configurable by the user (see ). These values for Enter/Tab are always shown at the bottom of the window at the status bar. Additionally the Tab section will have a "[change]" at the end if pressing Tab would switch the element's style, not create a new one.
Other ways to change an element's style are using the combo box at the top of the window, or pressing a short-cut key for each element style. See Help/Commands for a list of the keys.
Shift + Enter or CTRL + Enter will insert a forced linebreak.

sect2.title: Selecting text
sect2.para: When selecting text, one end of the selection is always fixed and the other one moves around with the cursor. You can select text by clicking and dragging with the mouse (right-click unselects), or by pressing CTRL + Space which sets the fixed point of the selection at current position and then moving around, or by pressing some movement key together with Shift (e.g. Shift + Up).
You can select the current scene with CTRL + A.
After you've selected the desired text, you can the cut/copy/paste commands to move text around, delete it, etc. You can also press Del to simply delete it. Note that this is not undoable in any way.

sect2.title: Auto-completion
sect2.para: Auto-completion saves typing in scene/character/transition elements by showing a list of other elements from the script that match the text in the current element. For example, if you've written the characters "MO" in a new character element, you'll see a list of all character elements that start with "MO" and if you want, you can select one of them and that text will complete the current element.
The auto-completion list only appears after you've written at least one character. If you want to see a list of all possible choices, write a single character and delete it.

You can move around in the list with the Up/Down/Page up/Page down keys. Pressing Enter will complete the text and start a new element, while pressing End will complete the text but will not start a new element. Pressing ESC will make the list go away.

sect2.title: Miscellaneous
sect2.para: When inserting a new empty parenthetical element, "()" will automatically be added to it and the cursor positioned in the middle. Likewise, when switching a parenthetical element to something else, if it only contains "()", it will be replaced by "" (empty). If you write a "(" in an empty dialogue or character element if will switch to a parenthetical element. If you press Enter or Tab at the ending ")" to start a new element, the ")" will stay in the parenthetical.
If you write "EXT." or "INT." (case doesn't matter) at the start of any element, it will switch to a scene element automatically.

chapter.title: Other commands
chapter.para: This chapter describes commands not discussed in other chapters.

sect1.title: File/New,open,save,save as,close,revert
sect1.para: These do what you'd expect them to do.

sect1.title: File/Print
sect1.para: This opens up the current script in your configured PDF viewer program, from which you can print it, or just see what it looks like.

sect1.title: File/Settings,load,save as
sect1.para: 'Settings' allows you to edit the various configurable settings of &blyte;. See .
&blyte; loads settings from a file named "default.conf" on startup. You can have as many config files as you want, and use the load/save as commands to manage them.
You can give a "--conf /home/me/someother.conf" command line parameter to &blyte; to have it start up with some other configuration file.

sect1.title: Edit/Cut,Copy,Paste
sect1.para: Cut, copy and paste work pretty much the same way as in every other program. Note that these commands only use &blyte;'s own internal clipboard so can't be used for copying text to/from other programs. For that, see below.

sect1.title: Edit/Copy to,paste from clipboard
sect1.para: These copy/paste text to the system wide clipboard so can be used for communicating with other programs. Note that if you copy text to the clipboard from &blyte;, you must keep &blyte; open until you've pasted the text to the destination program.

sect1.title: Edit/Select scene
sect1.para: Select all the text of the current scene.

sect1.title: Edit/Find & Replace
sect1.para: This opens a dialog allowing you to search for and possibly replace text. Usually it operates on all element styles, but if you press the "More" button, you can select the styles it operates on, which is useful renaming a character and so on.
Pressing Enter while the cursor is either the text box is equivalent to pressing the 'Find next' button. The Esc key will close the dialog.

If you're doing partial replacing, i.e. replacing some, but not all, occurrences of 'foo' with 'bar', the efficient way to do that is to press Tab until the focus is on the 'Find next' button, and then use the 'F' (Find next) and 'R' (Replace) keys on the keyboard. Press 'F' whenever you don't want to replace that occurrence, and 'R' when you do want to replace it.

sect1.title: Edit/Remove elements
sect1.para: 'Remove elements' opens a dialog allowing you to select one or more element styles to completely remove from the script. Be sure to only do this on copies of the script, because there is no way to get back the removed elements.

You can use this for e.g. removing notes before sending out copies of the script, or if you want a version of the script with only the dialog, only the action, or only the scene headers, or whatever else you can come up with.

sect1.title: Edit/Show formatting
sect1.para: This toggles whether formatting information is shown. It consists of blue lines drawn around each element, plus each line is prefixed with a red marker indicating the type of the line ending for that line. See fileformat.txt for information about the different marker types.

When using the 'Find errors' command, if you can't figure out what the error is, try switching this on to see if you have two elements where you thought you only had one, or something else that's not obvious in the normal display.

sect1.title: Script/Find next error
sect1.para: 'Find next error' searches through the script, starting from the cursor position, looking for errors. This means that to search the entire script for errors you should first position the cursor at the beginning of the script.

If it finds any errors, it positions the cursor on the line containing the error and displays a message box detailing the error. You should fix the error, back up a few lines, and activate the command again to search for more errors. Alternatively, if you don't want to fix the error right now, move the cursor down one line if you want to search for more errors.
It can detect the following errors:

listitem.para: Empty line, or a parenthetical element containing only ().
A character element that is not followed by a parenthetical or a dialogue element.
A parenthetical element that does not follow a character or a dialogue element.
A dialogue element that does not follow a character or a parenthetical element.

sect1.title: Script/Paginate
sect1.para: 'Paginate' simply repaginates the script. You normally don't need to run this if you have automatic repagination enabled, but the command is available for use when automatic repagination is disabled or you want immediate repagination after a large cut/paste operation.

sect1.title: Script/Title pages
sect1.para: 'Title pages' allows you to edit your script's title pages. You can have as many title pages as you want, or none at all.

At the top of the window are add/delete/move/next buttons. 'Add' adds a page, 'Delete' deletes the current page, 'Move' swaps the current page with the next page, and 'Next' changes the view to the next page.
The strings listbox contains all text strings for the current page. Select the text string you want to edit in this listbox, and use the add/delete buttons to add/delete text strings.
On the right side of the listbox is a coarse preview showing the approximate location of text strings on the current page, with the selected text string shown in red.

At the bottom of the window are the settings for the selected text string. There's the text itself, the position of its upper left corner as an offset from the paper's upper left corner, font, size, and style. 'Centered' means that the text is centered horizontally on the page.
Finally there's a 'Preview' button that you can use to get an accurate preview of all of the title pages.

sect1.title: Script/Headers
sect1.para: 'Headers' allows you to edit your script's headers. Headers are lines that are automatically added to the top of each page of the script, excluding title pages and the first page of the actual script.
Topmost in the window is a setting for how many empty lines you want inserted after your header lines.
After that is a listbox of all the strings in your headers. Select the text string you want to edit in this listbox, and use the add/delete buttons to add/delete text strings.
Below the listbox are the settings for the selected string. You can adjust the string text, style, alignment, line and positioning.

The text is first positioned according to the alignment setting, and then its horizontal starting position is adjusted by the number of characters given in 'X offset'. Note that this parameter can be negative, so for example, if you want your header string to start 2 characters before the left margin, select 'Alignment: Left' and 'X offset: -2'.
Any occurrences of '${PAGE}' in the text string will be replaced by the page number in the actual headers.
Finally there's a 'Preview' button that you can use to get an accurate preview of your headers.

sect1.title: Tools/Name database
sect1.para: 'Name database' opens a window allowing you browse and search through a database of more than 200,000 character names, each name being categorized by its nationality and sex.
On the left side of the window is a list of the name categories. The main groups available are nationalities, but there are some other interesting groups, e.g. Shakespeare, Medieval, Flowers etc.

Select the groups you want to search in, either a single one by simply clicking on it, or multiple ones by holding down CTRL and then clicking on multiple items. If you want to go back to the default of having all the groups selected, press the 'Select all' button at the bottom of the list.
On the upper right side of the window are the other search parameters. There's a text box in which you can write the text you want to search for, and two radio button groups.
The first one affects how your search string is used. The string has to match either a) at the start of the name, b) anywhere in the name or c) at the end of the name.
The second one selects whether male/female/both names are included in the search results.
The search is always case-insensitive, and a blank search string matches all names.

After having set all the search parameters, press the 'Search' button, at which point the results list will change to contain only the names matching the search parameters. A count of the matching names is shown at the bottom of the window.
You can select names from the result list and press 'Insert' to insert that name at your script at the current cursor position.

sect1.title: Tools/Character map
sect1.para: 'Character map' opens a window allowing you to insert any character from the supported ISO-8859-1 (i.e. Latin-1) character set into your script.

sect1.title: Tools/Compare scripts
sect1.para: You need two different versions of the same script open to use 'Compare scripts'. Select the older one as the first script and the newer one as the second script. &blyte; then goes through the scripts looking for changes between them and displays the results as a PDF file.

The PDF file contains only changed parts of the script. The changes are color coded: Deleted lines are red, added lines are green, non-changed lines (shown for context) are white, and marker lines for single-line changes are yellow. The changed parts are separated by two gray lines.

sect1.title: Help/Commands
sect1.para: 'Commands' opens a window showing all the keyboard commands.

sect1.title: Help/Manual
sect1.para: 'Manual' opens this manual you're reading right now.

sect1.title: Help/License
sect1.para: The license submenu contains three commands for dealing with licenses:

listitem.para: Shows information about the current license.
Opens a file dialog allowing you to load a new license.
Releases your license, i.e. goes back to evaluation mode.

sect1.title: Help/About
sect1.para: 'About' opens the about screen for &blyte;, showing information such as the version and the date this version was released on.

chapter.title: Settings
chapter.para: &blyte; has many settings you can configure to adjust the program's functioning to your preferences. Some of the settings just modify the user interface, and have no effect on the output of the program, while others have.

It's important to notice that these settings are not per-script; any changes you make affect all scripts that you open. If you want different settings for different scripts, you'll have to create separate configuration files.

The settings dialog is found under File/Settings. It has a list of categories on the left, the selected category's settings on the right, and three buttons, Apply, Cancel and OK on the bottom. Apply updates the settings to the ones given in the dialog and updates all open scripts to them, so you can easily preview your changes without closing the dialog. Note that you pressing Cancel after Apply has no effect, it only cancels changes that haven't yet been committed.
The following sections detail the various settings.

sect1.title: Auto-completion
sect1.para: Here you can define items to be added to the auto-completion lists for Scene, Character and Transition elements, and optionally disable auto-completion for any one of them.

Transition auto-completes are pretty generic so by default there are a few of them here, but the Scene and Character lists are empty. The main use for them are episodic TV shows, where you have a recurring cast of characters and locations, and it's nice to have them always available, even if they haven't yet been used in the current episode's script.

sect1.title: Colors
sect1.para: Color configuration; not much to explain here, besides the fact that these only affect the display, the PDF output is always black on white.

sect1.title: Display
sect1.para: The topmost listbox allows you to configure what font you want to use for normal, bold, italic, and bold + italic text. Note that you should use the same size fonts for each one.
The row spacing setting affects how many pixels there are between each row.

The 'Page break lines to show' setting affects how page breaks are shown. If you select 'None', they are not shown at all. 'Normal', you see solid gray lines in the scripts indicating actual page break positions. 'Normal + unadjusted', you see the solid lines, but you also see a dotted gray line, that shows where the page could have ended, but that the page break position was adjusted backwards to honor the settings in .

This is useful when you've finished your script and you're going through it trying to reduce the page count. If, for example, you have three lines, a Character, a Parenthetical, and a Dialogue element, all one line, and the unadjusted page break line is after the Parenthetical line, and the actual page break line is above the character line, you know that if you can trim just one line from the page, all three lines will then fit on the page instead of being pushed to the next page.

sect1.title: Elements
sect1.para: This is where you configure the formatting (and interaction) parameters for each element style.
At the top is a combo box where you specify what element style you're configuring. All things below that are element-specific settings.
The Screen/Print areas hold four checkboxes, Caps/Bold/Italic/Underlined, affecting the text style for the element. Screen affects your screen only, while Print affects PDF output.
The 'Empty lines / 10 before' setting is linespacing before the element, divided by 10. So a value of 10 means normal linespacing, 15 means 1.5 linespacing, 20 is double linespacing, etc.
The 'Empty lines / 10 between' is the same, but for intra-element linespacing, i.e. consecutive lines of the same element have this much space between them.

The Indent and Width settings specify in characters how much the element is indented (i.e. set off from the left margin) and how wide it is. 10 characters (in the default 12-point font) equal one inch.

The 'Enter/Tab creates' and 'Tab/Shift+Tab switches to' affect what element is created when Enter or Tab is pressed in this element style, or what element style Tab/Shift+Tab switches the element to. See for more information.

sect1.title: Misc
sect1.para: The default script directory setting allows you to specify the default directory for File/Open dialog on program startup.

'Auto-capitalize sentences', if on, well, auto-capitalizes sentences as you write them. If it capitalizes something you don't want capitalized, write another letter, and then replace the capitalized letter by a lowercase one.

The 'Confirm deletes' setting allows you to configure how many lines you can delete without confirmation. It exists because otherwise it'd be too easy to select a large block of text, press Delete, and see all your work disappear.
'Lines to scroll per mouse wheel event' needs no explaining.

sect1.title: Pagination
sect1.para: This category contains settings that affect pagination of the script.

The first two settings affect how many Action and Dialogue lines there must be left at the end of a page to allow breaking at that position. Note that this only affects elements that are broken in the middle, i.e. if you have a one-line element, the page can always end after that.

'Include scene continueds', if enabled, inserts "(CONTINUED)" at the end of each page that has a scene that continues to the next page, and "CONTINUED: (n)" (n = number of CONTINUED pages for current scene, omitted if n = 1) for each page that continues a scene from previous page(s).

'Auto-paginate interval' defines how often to repaginate the script automatically. If you have a particularly slow machine, you might want to increase this number. Note that automatic repagination is only done when you modify the script, so you can't just sit back and wait for the repagination to happen, you have to keep making changes. (You can always use Script/Paginate if you want immediate repagination.)

sect1.title: Paper
sect1.para: Here you can configure your output paper size and margins. You can use A4, Letter, or a custom paper size. At the bottom of the page is shown the number of lines that will fit on a page with the given settings.

sect1.title: PDF
sect1.para: Here you can configure parameters affecting the PDF output.

First you need to specify what application you want to use as your PDF viewer. On Windows, this is usually Adobe Acrobat, and the path is something like "C:\Program Files\Adobe\Acrobat 6.0\Reader\AcroRd32.exe". On Linux, you can also use Adobe Acrobat, path being something like "/usr/local/Acrobat5/bin/acroread". xpdf is another program you could use if you want, but it's not as good as Adobe Acrobat.
You can also specify arguments to give to the program.
The font size specifies the font size to use. 12 is the default, and you should only deviate from this if you have a very good reason.

'Check script for errors before print, export or compare', if checked, causes the program to run 'Script/Find next error' for the whole script automatically before print/export/compare operations. This is to avoid printing 100 pages and then finding there's an error on one of them, fixing of which causes repagination of the whole script, and having to print all the 100 pages again.
'Include scene numbers' causes scene numbers to be inserted to the left and right of each Scene element. This is usually only done for scripts in production.
Show margins/line numbers can be considered debug options, for they have no use in normal operation, but can be useful if you're trying to figure out printing related errors.

chapter.title: Import and export
chapter.para: This chapter discusses the import/export support of the program.

sect1.title: Import
sect1.para: Existing screenplays can currently be imported from only one file format: as formatted ASCII text. The following section documents the format these files should have for optimal import processing.

sect2.title: ASCII Text files
sect2.para: ASCII text files should have the following characteristics:

listitem.para: Each element style should begin at a unique column. An exception is that Scene and Action can begin at the same column.
There should only be one such starting column per element style, i.e. all dialogue should begin at the same column, it shouldn't sometimes start at column 25, sometimes at 27, etc.
No production markings, e.g. scene numbers, page numbers, cast lists, or anything like that.
Elements should be separated by a single empty line.

sect2.para: Below is a short example of the kind of format best recognized by &blyte;.
sect2.screen:
EXT. OCEAN - NIGHT
The package hits the water and is submerged. A few seconds later, a rapidly inflating liferaft appears.
The people land into the water in their parachutes. They dispose of them and swim toward the liferaft.
INT. LIFERAFT - NIGHT
They're all aboard, taking off their clothes. When they're all naked, Sarah gathers the wet clothes, throws them out, and closes the entrance to the tent-like liferaft. The men openly admire Sarah's body, as she opens a storage locker and takes out dry clothes for everyone which they then put on.
KEVIN I know a great way to warm up.
SARAH Sorry, I got over the "older men" thing a while back.
KEVIN Anytime you have a flashback, let me know.
Something starts beeping.

sect1.title: Export
sect1.para: You can export the script as a PDF file or as a formatted ASCII text file. Both are found in the File/Export dialog, which allows you to choose which one to export as. If you export as a text file, &blyte; will ask whether you want the page markers included or not. If you're planning on importing the script to some other program, you shouldn't include them, otherwise you probably should.

chapter.title: Reports
chapter.para: This chapter discusses the various report types &blyte; can generate.

sect1.title: Dialogue chart
sect1.para: 'Dialogue chart' first opens a window allowing you to specify what to include in the generated chart. The 'Sorted by:' options select what orderings to include, while the 'Characters appearing on a single page' option, if unselected, leaves out all characters appearing on a single page only from the generated chart. It's useful for long scripts that have many such characters, or otherwise if you want to concentrate on the more important characters.
It then generates a chart in PDF format with one page for each selected ordering and shows that.
The chart has two axes: The horizontal one, with page numbers increasing from left to right, and the vertical one, with characters ordered by the current page's sort criterion from top to bottom.
If a character speaks on a given page, he will have a black mark on that page's position on the chart.
Every other line has a light gray background to allow easier visual matching of distant markings to character names.

You can use this chart in many ways. For example, you can at a glance see if one of your side characters disappears for 50 pages in the middle of the script, whether the villain is introduced too late, and so on.

At the top is another chart, this one showing the dialogue density for each page. Dialogue density is calculated as "number of dialogue/character/parenthetical lines on page divided by total number of non-empty lines on page". By looking at the chart you can easily see where the action scenes are by the lower dialogue density in those pages.

sect1.title: Character report
sect1.para: 'Character report' first opens a window allowing you to specify what to include in the generated report. You can select what characters are included, and what kind of information to include for each character:

listitem.para: Total number of speeches, total number of lines, the percentage of all the dialogue lines in the script that this character speaks (i.e. 25% would mean this character has one-fourth of the total dialogue in the script), average number of lines per speech, total words, average number of words per speech and average number of characters per word.
Number of pages this character speaks on, followed by a list of all of those pages.
A list of all the locations this character speaks in, preceded by the number of lines spoken at each location.

sect1.para: It then generates a report in PDF format containing the selected information and opens that file.

appendix.title: File format
appendix.para: The file format used by &blyte; for scripts is open and documented, and third parties are encouraged to add support for the format in their programs and/or write utility programs that use the file format in some way, e.g. for generating detailed reports from scripts.

For more information, see the file 'fileformat.txt' in the program's installation directory, and read through the sample script file provided. If you still have questions about the file format, feel free to contact us by email.
